Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
J. B. S. (Jacob Benjamin Salutsky) Hardman Papers
Hardman, J. B. S. (Jacob Benjamin Salutsky), 1882-1968
Hardman, Mrs. Virginia Mishnun
TAM.050
23.5 Linear Feet in 47 manuscript boxes and one oversize flat box.
1908-1970 J. B. S. (Jacob Benjamin Salutsky) Hardman (1882-1968) was a Russian-born author, social philosopher, and editor and leader who served the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America as director of education and cultural activities and as editor of its organ, The Advance(1920-44). He also edited Naye Welt, a Yiddish-language socialist weekly, and American Labor Monthly. He organized the American Labor Press Association, and was chairman of the Inter-Union Institute for Labor and Democracy (publisher of Labor and Nation, which he founded and edited from 1944-1953). The papers contain correspondence (some in Russian and Yiddish), materials apparently collected for an unrealized autobiographical project titled, "Odyssey," other biographical materials, numerous drafts of published and unpublished writings, clippings, and files on his labor and political activities containing a mix of correspondence, internal documents and printed ephemera. Materials are in English, Russian, and Yiddish.
Processing Information
Non-print materials were separated from this collection during initial processing and were established as a separate collection, the J.B.S. (Jacob Benjamin Salutsky) Hardman Photographs (PHOTOS 188). In 2013, the photograph collection was reincorporated into the J.B.S. (Jacob Benjamin Salutsky) Hardman Papers.
Immediate Source of Acquisition
Donated by Mrs. Virginia Mishnun Hardman, 1971. The accession numbers associated with this gift are 1971.005 and 1971.006.
Conditions Governing Access
Materials are open without restrictions.
Historical/Biographical Note
J. B. S. (Jacob Benjamin Salutsky) Hardman (1882-1968) social philosopher, author, editor and leader in the development of American trade unionism for over sixty years, was born in Vilna in 1882. Because of his revolutionary and trade-union activities he was exiled in 1908. He came to the United States where he became active in the Socialist Party and the trade-union movement. He was editor of Naye Welt, a socialist weekly, and of American Labor Monthly, also a socialist-oriented journal, 1923-1924; director of education and cultural activities of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America for twenty-four years and editor of the union's official organ, The Advance. He organized and was president of the American Labor Press Association and served as chairman of the Inter-Union Institute for Labor and Democracy, the publisher of Labor and Nation, which he founded and edited from 1944-1953.
Sources:
J. B. S. Hardman, 1882-1968: Biographical Sketch, by Felicja Figa and Franklin L. Jonas ( Bulletin of the Tamiment Library, no. 48, March 1973, pp. 1-6).
Scope and Content Note
The papers contain personal correspondence (1908-1953), business correspondence (1925-1968), biographical material, writings by Hardman on labor and politics, manuscript and published articles by others sent to him for editorial comment, material on labor and political activities, and clippings on labor-related issues. Hardman was active in many organizations, including the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, Inter-Union Institute for Labor and Democracy, American Labor Press Association, Columbia University's Council for Research in the Social Sciences, Brookwood Labor College, the Jewish Socialist Federation, Workers Party of America, Conference for Progressive Labor Action, and other organizations. His work and activities within these organizations are documented in the collection.
Arrangement
Files are arranged alphabetically (sometimes by keyword) within each series, except for correspondence, which is arranged chronologically.
The files are grouped into six series:
Series I: Personal Correspondence
Series II: Biographical
Series III: Business Correspondence
Series IV: Writings
Series V: Labor and Political Activities
Series VI: Clippings
Files are arranged alphabetically (sometimes by keyword) within each series, except for correspondence, which is arranged chronologically.
The files are grouped into six series:
Missing Title
I, Personal Correspondence
II, Biographical
III, Business Correspondence
IV, Writings
V, Labor and Political Activities
VI, Clippings
Conditions Governing Use
Tamiment Library has no information about copyright ownership for this collection and is not authorized to grant permission to publish or reproduce materials from it. Materials in this collection, which were created in 1908-1970, are expected to enter the public domain in 2039.
Preferred Citation
Identification of item, date; J.B.S. (Jacob Benjamin Salutsky) Hardman Papers; TAM 050; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

Series I: Personal Correspondence1910-1967
Scope and Content Note
Early personal correspondence, much of it in Russian and Yiddish, is with family members, including Hardman's wife, Hannah Goldenstein Hardman. Later correspondence with Louis Corey, Babette Deutsch, John Dewey, Waldo Frank, and C. E. Ruthenberg relates chiefly to Hardman's writing and editorial activities for the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America (1920-1944).Personal Correspondenceundated11Personal Correspondence191012Personal Correspondence191113Personal CorrespondenceJan 191214Personal CorrespondenceFeb 191215Personal CorrespondenceMar 1912-Aug 191216Personal CorrespondenceOct 1912-Dec 191217Personal CorrespondenceJan 1913-May 191321Personal CorrespondenceApr 1913-May 191322Personal CorrespondenceJun 1913-Jul 191323Personal CorrespondenceAug 191324Personal CorrespondenceSep 1913-Nov 191325Personal Correspondence1914-191826Personal Correspondence191931Personal Correspondence192032Personal Correspondence192133Personal CorrespondenceJan 1922-Apr 192234Personal CorrespondenceMay 1922-Dec 192235Personal Correspondence192336Personal Correspondence192437Personal Correspondence192541Personal Correspondence192642Personal Correspondence192743Personal Correspondence192844Personal Correspondence192945Personal Correspondence193046Personal Correspondence193147Personal Correspondence193248Personal Correspondence193349Personal Correspondence193451Personal Correspondence193552Personal Correspondence193653Personal Correspondence193754Personal Correspondence193855Personal Correspondence193956Personal Correspondence1940-194257Personal Correspondence1943-1947 , 1949 , 195158Personal Correspondence195359Personal Correspondence1962-1967510Series II: Biographical1908-1973
Scope and Content Note
Biographical material includes many topical files of material (including correspondence, speeches, notes, etc.) apparently gathered by Hardman for an unrealized autobiographical project, entitled "Odyssey," and files on Hardman's family and his early life, his associations with Amalgamated Clothing Workers, Brookwood Labor College (1932-1933), and the Jewish Socialist Federation (1920-1921).Documents, Personal (name change, naturalization, Russian passport)1908-1909, 1924, 1953, 197361Obituaries and Letters of Condolences196862Odyssey Files Files: Jewish Socialist Federation-Financial Mattersundated63Odyssey Files: Correspondence1920-195664Odyssey Files: Amalgamated Clothing Workers-Hardman Speechesundated65Odyssey Files: Amalgamated Clothing Workers-Hardman Speeches1922-194466Odyssey Files: American Labor Monthly192367Odyssey Files: Brookwood Labor Collegeundated68Odyssey Files: Personal Correspondence (in Russian and Yiddish)ca.1909-194669Odyssey Files: C.I.O.-New York State Radio, Press, and Education Committeeundated610Odyssey Files: Oral History Transcript (for Columbia University, with correspondence and notes)1962-1963611Odyssey Files: Family Mattersundated71Odyssey Files: Mrs. Hannah Hardmanundated72Odyssey Files: Diary Notesundated73Odyssey Files: Book Contracts and Correspondence re: Publishingundated74Odyssey Files: Documentary Manuscripts (Biographical Notes)undated75Odyssey Files: Documentary Manuscripts (Biographical Notes)undated76Odyssey Files: Encyclopedia of Social Sciencesundated77Testimonial Dinner (material from scrapbook)Nov 17, 194278Union Membership Cards and Other Memorabiliaundated79Series III: Business Correspondence1925-1970
Scope and Content Note
In the course of his work as chairman of the Inter-Union Institute he corresponded with Harold L. Ickes, Ludwig Lore, C. Wright Mills, Philip Murray, A. J. Muste, Selig Perlman, and Raymond Postgate, among others. Other correspondence reflects his work as editor of Labor and Nation (1945-1953), as president of the American Labor Press Association during World War II, and as research director of the Labor Leadership Study sponsored by Columbia University's Council for Research in the Social Sciences (1949-1960).Business Correspondence (2 letters)192581Business Correspondence (2 letters)1930, 193282Business Correspondence (2 letters)193483Business Correspondence (2 letters)193984Business Correspondence (15 letters)194085Business Correspondence (8 letters)194186Business Correspondence (4 letters)1942-194387Business Correspondence (14 letters)194488Business Correspondence (37 letters)194589Business Correspondence (68 letters)1946810Business Correspondence (19 letters)1947811Business Correspondence (14 letters)1948812Business Correspondence (88 letters)1949813Business Correspondence (124 letters)1950814Business Correspondence (181 letters)1951815Business Correspondence (120 letters)1952816Business Correspondence re: Labor and Nation Proposal195291Business Correspondence (87 letters)195392Business Correspondence (95 letters)195493Business Correspondence (37 letters)195594Business Correspondence (19 letters)195695Business Correspondence (27 letters)195796Business Correspondence (53 letters)195897Business Correspondence (28 letters)195998Business Correspondence (26 letters)196099Business Correspondence (65 letters)1961910Business Correspondence (27 letters)1962101Business Correspondence (36 letters)1963102Business Correspondence (33 letters)1964103Business Correspondence (59 letters)1965104Business Correspondence (35 letters)1966105Business Correspondence (29 letters)1967106Business Correspondence1968-1970107Business Correspondence (23 letters)undated108Series IV: Writings1910-1970

Hardman's Work1928-19293012Yiddish Articles by Hardman1910-19653013Series V: Labor and Political Activities1923-1967
Scope and Content Note
This series includes records of the Inter-Union Institute for Labor and Democracy (1942-1953), incomplete committee minutes and copies of papers presented at the Columbia University Seminars on Labor (1948-1967), and material relating to the Hardman's expulsion from the Workers Party of America in 1923, his involvement in the American Workers Party in the mid-1930s, records of the Conference for Progressive Labor Action, a survey on attitudes of labor leaders done for Elmo Roper and Louis Harris by Hardman in 1950, and material on Hanna Goldstein Hardman's studies at the New York School of Philanthropy and her work on immigrants.Letter to a Confused Liberal1951311Mature Collective Bargaining: Prospects and Problems, Institute of Industrial Relations, University of
